Executive Summary---Risk Management Plan for Carpenter Company, Conover, NC---40 CFR 68.155

In 1948, E. Rhodes Carpenter began distributing cushioning materials to the furniture industry.  By 1956, Carpenter's company began manufacturing the flexible foam that it marketed to the furniture and home furnishings industries.  In 1962, Carpenter built the first continuous foam pouring line in Richmond, VA.  Due to Carpenter's hard work, honesty, and integrity his company grew rapidly.  In 1972, Carpenter opened his fourth polyurethane foam manufacturing facility in Conover, North Carolina.  Carpenter Company, Conover, NC has been a major supplier to the furniture, bedding, and home furnishings industries for over 44 years.  In addition to polyurethane foam, the Conover Plant produces polyester fiber products for similar cushioning properties as found in the polyurethane foam.  The polyurethane foam manufacturing process has seen numerous changes over the years in respect to chemistry, chemicals, government regulations, and the ever-changing needs of our customers.  It is this polyurethane foam pouring process that is subject to the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Risk Management Plan Rule.

The original Risk Management Plan (RMP) for Carpenter Company-Conover Plant was submitted in 1999, the year that the Clean Air Act mandated the EPA to publish regulations and guidance on chemical accident prevention at facilities that use certain hazardous substances.  These regulations and guidance are contained in their Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule.

The information required from facilities under the RMP rule helps local fire, police, and emergency response personnel prepare for and respond to chemical emergencies.  Making RMPs available to the public also fosters communication and awareness to improve accident prevention and emergency response practices at the local level.  The RMP rule requires companies that use certain toxic and flammable chemicals to develop a Risk

Management Plan.   

Regulations in 40 CFR Part 68 requires an RMP resubmittal, if significant changes within the process occurs.  Also, a mandatory resubmittal is required every five years.  Since 1999, Carpenter Company-Conover Plant has had several process changes that resulted in a resubmittal of the RMP.  The first RMP resubmittal was in 2004, the five-year anniversary of the original 1999 submittal.  In 2006, a new foam pouring line, (Hennecke line) was constructed and began producing foam on July 12, 2006.  Due to some lacking process knowledge, at that time, the old pouring line was kept in operation to produce several specialty foams that could not be poured on the new pouring line.  This new Hennecke line, which incorporated carbon dioxide as the primary blowing agent, stemmed an RMP resubmittal.  This RMP change was resubmitted in March, 2007.

As a result of new chemistry and technology breakthroughs, the Hennecke line was updated to pour all of the foam recipes.  The old pour line was scrapped after its last pour on April 3, 2009.  The old line used Pentane as its primary blowing agent, while the Hennecke line uses mostly carbon dioxide. On July 9, 2009, the remaining Pentane was removed from the storage tank.  Under RMP rule, the removal of Pentane initiated a significant change, therefore, a resubmittal of RMP occurred on September 4, 2009.  Pentane was not used for the next year. 

Due to technological advances, Carpenter-Conover began experimenting with Pentane on the Hennecke line to produce new foam recipes.  These new foams were very successful.  Their success led to the need to inventory Pentane again in quantities above the 10,000-pound threshold.  To take advantage of more attractive prices, Carpenter-Conover began exploring the possibility of bringing in full railcars of Pentane once again.  Before these larger purchases could occur, the RMP had to be updated, for this, another significant process change.  On March 24, 2011, Carpenter-Conover

resubmitted its RMP once again.  The five-year anniversary of this 2011 resubmission was April 7, 2016, necessitating a new resubmittal.  Since 2016, Pentane usage has decreased steadily.  Due to this low usage rate, Carpenter-Conover management decided to allow the Pentane level in the storage tank to drop and permanently remain below the 10,000 lb. threshold allowing its removal from this Risk Management Plan.  On July 30, 2019, the Pentane inventory level dropped below the 10,000 lb. threshold and will be held below 10,000 lbs. using administrative controls.  The removal of Pentane from this Risk Management Plan in 2019 necessitated an RMP resubmittal.   2024 signifies a five-year anniversary, therefore this RMP resubmittal is required. 

In accordance with the rules in 40 CFR 68.155 (guidelines on the Executive Summary) the following areas will be discussed herein:

A)	The accidental release prevention and emergency policies
B)	The stationary source and regulated substances handled
C)	The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps
D)	The five-year accident history
E)	The emergency response program
F)	Planned changes to improve safety 

A)	The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Carpenter-Conover is committed to abide with all federal, state, county, and local laws and regulations concerning the proper storage, handling, and use of all chemicals whether toxic, flammable, or otherwise.  Carpenter-Conover is committed to its Guiding Principles, Safety Policy, and Environmental Policy.  These guidance materials "put down on paper" the company's obligation to protect its employees, customers, and beyond our property lines---our neighbors and the environment.

An Emergency Response Plan for Carpenter-Conover has been developed in the "Integrated Contingency Plan."  This Plan includes the procedures for informing applicable Emergency Response agencies should an accidental release occur.  Also, the In

tegrated Contingency Plan provides guidelines for the Emergency Coordinator(s) to respond to all emergency situations.  These guidelines include location of all hazardous chemicals and other substances, listing of alternate Emergency Coordinators with contact information, assembly of Carpenter-Conover's employee-staffed Spill Team, telephone numbers for all emergency response agencies and the closest local hospital, and provides the division manager or his designee the government agencies that must be notified after an emergency situation has abated.  

In the event of a major release of a hazardous substance, all U.S. Carpenter locations have contracted with Clean Harbors Environmental Services, Inc. to coordinate and execute a massive clean-up effort.  

B)	The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled  

Carpenter-Conover is located at 2009 Keisler Dairy Road, Conover, North Carolina 28613, and manufactures polyester fiber and polyurethane foam products for the furniture, bedding, and home furnishings industries.  It is the polyurethane foam pouring process that incorporates the only remaining RMP regulated substance.  This substance, toluene diisocyanate (TDI) is inventoried above its 10,000-pound threshold, thus requiring RMP inclusion.

Toluene diisocyanate (TDI), an 80/20% mix of the 2, 4 and 2, 6 isomers, is used as a reactant in the foam pouring process.  TDI is received primarily via railcars that contain approximately 190,000 pounds of product.  These railcars are queued on the track at the outdoor holding area until needed.  When required, the railcar is moved indoors to the railcar unloading area.  Transfer hoses and related equipment is connected and the unloading process begins.  TDI is transferred from the railcar to three 12,000-gallon storage tanks located in the interior tank farm.  From these three tanks, the TDI is transferred to a 32,875-gallon tank which feeds the pouring line.  These four TDI tanks are seated in concrete secondary co

ntainment structures that can completely capture the tank's content in the event of a total tank failure.  TDI is pumped from the 32,875-gallon storage tank through a strainer, filter, and heat exchanger before arriving to the mixing head.  In the mixing head, TDI is blended with polyol, water, carbon dioxide (CO2), pentane (used in specialty foams), pigments, fillers, and other minor components.  The resulting chemical reaction produces polyurethane foam.

C)	The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps 

Carpenter-Conover abides fully with EPA's Clean Air Act Section 112(r):  Accidental Release Prevention/Risk Management Plan Rule.   Carpenter-Conover's Risk Management Plan has been subject to five dedicated inspections by the North Carolina Department of Environmental Quality - Division of Air Quality (the last on December 15, 2019) and was found in complete compliance.  Further, this facility is in good standing with all of the N.C. DEQ's Divisions (Air Quality, Water Quality, and the Departments of Waste Management and Storm Water.)

Concerning TDI, the four storage tanks are equipped with electronic overfill alarms with automatic pump shutoff and are vented through a bank of activated charcoal filters to remove all of the TDI vapors.  The foam pouring process is equipped with a continuous TDI vapor monitor with electronic and audible alarms.

Carpenter-Conover has an in-house Spill Team that is composed of foam pouring personnel, other plant hourly employees, as well as several members of management.  All Spill team members have HAZWOPER training "Hazardous Materials Technician Level."  Every year, Spill Team members attend refresher courses to maintain their "Technician Level" certification. 

D)	The Five-Year Accident History

For the five years prior to the re-submission of this RMP, Carpenter-Conover has NOT had an accidental release of the regulated substance, Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI), where exposure to the su

bstance, their reaction products, overpressure generated by an explosion involving the substance, or radiant heat generated by a fire involving the substance led to any of the following offsite:  death, injury or response or restoration activities for an exposure of an environmental receptor.

E)	The Emergency Response Program 

An Emergency Response procedure for Carpenter-Conover is located in the Integrated Contingency Plan.  This Integrated Contingency Plan is comprised of:  topographic maps of the outside and site layouts of the inside of the facility, listing of the emergency coordinators with fields of expertise, parameters in which lead to the implementation of the integrated contingency plan, emergency response procedures, listing of emergency equipment at the responder's disposal, coordination agreements with the Conover Fire Department, Conover Police Department, Catawba Valley Medical Center, and Clean Harbors Environmental Services, Inc., the evacuation plan, and listing of the required government reports that must be filed if the Integrated Contingency Plan is implemented. 

All employees, both hourly and salaried, of the foam pouring process have been trained at the "Technician Level" of OSHA's HAZWOPER standard.  Other hourly employees, located throughout the plant, as well as some members of management, have also been trained at the "Technician Level."  

In the event of a fire, Carpenter-Conover's maintenance personnel make up a Fire Brigade, whose sole purpose is to assist the Conover Fire Department.  This fire brigade operates the facility's fire suppression, alarm, and security systems.  These fire brigade members have been trained at the "First Responder Operations Level" of the HAZWOPER standard.

F)	Planned Changes to Improve Safety 

The Reinhart Technical Center (RTC), in Richmond, VA, is Carpenter Company's state-of-the-art Research and Development Center.  At RTC, chemists, chemical engineers, and other highly skilled personnel are const

antly reviewing and "re-inventing" the foam pouring process.  RTC personnel has developed and refined the many recipes that Carpenter's pouring plants produce every day.  Foremost at RTC is the safety of Carpenter's employees, our plant's neighbors, and the environment that we live in.  Most of our safety procedures have been developed by RTC experts.  RTC strives daily to make the polyurethane foam pouring process safe.  

At Carpenter-Conover, we recognize that the post-9/11 world that we live in calls for prudent measures to plant security.  To ensure and maintain a secure facility, Carpenter-Conover has implemented the following:
¿	The entire manufacturing facility is fenced.
¿	There is a security guard at the entrance gate continuously (24/7/365.)
¿	Employees must enter their personalized access code to enter the building.
¿	All approved visitors must sign our visitor's log and are escorted at all times. 
¿	Before hiring, a background check and drug test is performed on prospective employees.

A Written Hazard Communication Program was adopted in June, 2015.
This program was established to educate our employees of the hazards associated with the chemicals used at Carpenter-Conover.  This Written Hazard Communication Program complies fully with the United Nations' Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labeling of Chemicals (GHS) and OSHA's Hazard Communication Standard (HCS.)

Carpenter Company has joined with its property loss insurance carrier, FM Global, to establish guidelines and parameters for the safe receiving, storage, and use of TDI in the polyurethane foam pouring plants across the United States and Europe.  

Safety is the most important thing we do at Carpenter-Conover.  Our utmost goal is for---all of us---to return home to our loved ones at the end of each day.
